message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. During the early stages of infection, pentameric IgM antibodies are the predominant form circulating in the serum. After several days, pentameric IgM is replaced by monomeric IgG antibodies.

We refer to the articles on the immune system and antibodies on Wikipedia for help. During the early stages of an infection, pentameric IgM antibodies are the first to be produced by the body in response to the infection. These antibodies are larger and have multiple binding sites, allowing them to efficiently neutralize and clear the pathogen. Later in the infection, smaller dimeric IgG antibodies will be produced, which are more efficient at binding to and neutralizing the pathogen. Therefore, in this case, the antibodies circulating in the student's serum are likely pentamers.

They are made up of five monomer subunits, and each subunit contains two heavy chains and two light chains. Pentamers are especially effective in neutralizing viruses and bacteria.
